_header: Woe worth debate that never hath peace
Note: Same as stanza 67 of Court of Sapience (168, 5365); st. 99 of Ashby’ Active Policy of a Prince (3446); for a longer text see 6776.
_description: One stanza pronouncing curses, occurring separately — one stanza rhyme royal

BodAsh1152.Editions:
Black,  William Henry. 
             Catalogi Codicum Manuscriptorum Bibliothecae Bodleianae…Pars X,
                A…Catalogue of the Manuscripts bequeathed…by Elias Ashmole.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1845: 1047.

BLAdd60577.Transcription:
Woo worthe debate þat neuyr may haue peceWoo worthe penaunce
                    that asshith no piteWoo worthe vengeaunce whiche mercy may not seceWoo
                    worthe that Iugemente þat hathe none equiteWoo worthe þat truthe
                    þat hathe noo charyteWoo worthe þat Iuge which may noo gylte
                    saveAnd woo worth þat ryght þat may noo fauoure haue
BLAdd60577.Facsimiles:
Wilson,  Edward. 
             “Introduction.” 
             The Winchester Anthology. A Facsimile of British Library Additional
                Manuscript 60577. With an account of the music by 
                    Iain
                    Fenlon. 
         Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1981.

HunHM144.Transcription:
Wo worthe debate þat neuer may haue peaseWo worthe penaunce
                    þat askith no pyteWo worthe vengeaunce whiche mercy may not
                    seaseWo worthe þat Iugement þat hathe none equiteWo worthe
                    þat trouthe þat hathe no chariteWo worthe þat Iuge þat
                    may no gilt saueWo worthe þat right þat may no fauor
                    haue
HunHM144.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James. 
             “Chaucer and Lydgate Fragments.” 
             Notes and Queries
         5th ser. 9 (1878): 342-3: 343.
Bühler,  Kurt. 
             “Lydgate’s Horse, Sheep and Goose and Huntington MS HM
                144.” 
             Modern Language Notes
         55 (1940): 563-69: 567.
